byline.original: By VIVIAN YEE and MIREYA NAVARRO

abstract: Distrust of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio's affordable housing strategy runs deep in Brooklyn, where longtime residents fear they will be pushed out by luxury apartment developers hoping to capitalize on influx of wealthy newcomers; anger simmering in East New York and other areas poses challenge to de Blasio's plan to add thousands of lower-income apartments, and also raises questions about whether city can build without further gentrification.
lead_paragraph: Many New York residents, especially in Brooklyn, say the influx of market-rate apartments called for in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plans could gut neighborhoods, not preserve them.

headline.main: Some See Risk in de Blasio’s Bid to Add Housing
headline.print_headline: Some in City See Mayor’s Housing Plan as Threat

snippet: Many New York residents, especially in Brooklyn, say the influx of market-rate apartments called for in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plans could gut neighborhoods, not preserve them.
